original_data.question: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because he was vomiting and seemed abnormally sleepy at home. On presentation, he is found to be confused and very lethargic. His parents said that he has had a fever and cough for several days prior to presentation and was given an over the counter medication. Physical exam of this patient reveals mild hepatomegaly and dry mucous membranes. Which of the following effects would the drug most likely also have on the nephron?

options.A: Constriction of afferent arteriole and no effect on efferent arteriole
options.B: Dilation of afferent arteriole and no effect on efferent arteriole
options.C: No effect on afferent arteriole and constriction of efferent arteriole
options.D: No effect on afferent arteriole and dilation of efferent arteriole

model_response:
The correct answer is D. The drug most likely has caused systemic vasoconstriction which would lead to decreased renal blood flow. The afferent arteriole would constrict in response to decreased renal blood flow and the efferent arteriole would dilate in order to maintain glomerular filtration pressure.

Answer: OPTION D IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Hospital department responsible for the administration and provision of immediate medical or surgical care to the emergency patient.
The forcible expulsion of the contents of the STOMACH through the MOUTH.

The result for a quantitative observation is above the upper limit of the reference range (as defined for the respective test procedure).

Synonym: Above high normal
Aspects of peoples' living conditions that may and can impact people's health and/or well-being. These factors may be physical (e.g., housing quality) or social circumstances (e.g., living alone).
To show or display; the act of presenting something to sight or view: how something looks.
A mental state characterized by bewilderment, emotional disturbance, lack of clear thinking, and perceptual disorientation.
Characterized by a lack of vitality or energy.
Persons functioning as natural, adoptive, or substitute parents. The heading includes the concept of parenthood as well as preparation for becoming a parent.
An abnormal elevation of body temperature, usually as a result of a pathologic process.

A sudden, audible expulsion of air from the lungs through a partially closed glottis, preceded by inhalation. It is a protective response that serves to clear the trachea, bronchi, and/or lungs of irritants and secretions, or to prevent aspiration of foreign materials into the lungs.
The time for Earth to make a complete rotation on its axis; ordinarily divided into twenty-four hours, equal to 86 400 seconds. This also refers to a specific day.
To show or display; the act of presenting something to sight or view: how something looks.
Drugs intended for human or veterinary use, presented in their finished dosage form. Included here are materials used in the preparation and/or formulation of the finished dosage form.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
Enlargement of the liver.

An EPITHELIUM with MUCUS-secreting cells, such as GOBLET CELLS. It forms the lining of many body cavities, such as the DIGESTIVE TRACT, the RESPIRATORY TRACT, and the reproductive tract. Mucosa, rich in blood and lymph vessels, comprises an inner epithelium, a middle layer (lamina propria) of loose CONNECTIVE TISSUE, and an outer layer (muscularis mucosae) of SMOOTH MUSCLE CELLS that separates the mucosa from submucosa.
A phenomenon that follows and is caused by some previous phenomenon.
Drugs intended for human or veterinary use, presented in their finished dosage form. Included here are materials used in the preparation and/or formulation of the finished dosage form.
The functional units of the kidney, consisting of the glomerulus and the attached tubule.
